title: Global business activity slows but optimism remains for the year ahead
text:
Good evening,

New waves of Covid-19 infections, supply chain problems and persistent inflation continue to hold back business recovery, according to a closely watched global survey.

In the eurozone, initial estimates for January from IHS Markit's purchasing managers' index showed activity growing at its slowest rate in 11 months. The overall PMI reading was 52.4, down from 53.3 in December. A score above 50 indicates a majority of businesses are reporting higher activity than a month ago.

Inflation remains a key concern, with businesses saying the price of goods and services had risen at the fastest rate since the survey started in 2002.

The sectoral result for services fell to a nine-month low of 51.2, although separate Financial Times analysis of alternative eurozone indicators, such as cinema ticket sales and hotel bookings, suggested pandemic damage was not as severe as in previous waves. Manufacturing, especially in Germany, fared better, as an easing of supply chain bottlenecks helped lift the sector's score to a five-month high of 59.

Activity in the UK similarly fell to an 11-month low of 53.4 in January, from 53.6 the previous month. Inflationary concerns were again to the fore, with higher energy costs and wages driving input costs up at the second fastest rate since the survey began in 1998. As in the eurozone, manufacturing outpaced services, which were hit harder by coronavirus restrictions. However, there was more optimism on future prospects, with expectations for the year ahead at their most upbeat since the summer.

There was also some positive news from manufacturing in Japan, where activity grew at its fastest rate in four years. This was despite the fact that the overall PMI figure fell to 48.8, from 52.5 last month, as services were hit badly by a new wave of infections and restrictions.

The US experienced the most dramatic fall in overall PMI, with the aggregate score falling from 57 to an 18-month low of 50.8, as new infections exacerbated supply problems and labour shortages, slowing output in manufacturing as well as services.

Chris Williamson, chief business economist at IHS Markit, said soaring virus cases had brought the US economy “to a near standstill” at the start of the year. Demand, however, was less affected, he noted, suggesting growth will pick up again once restrictions are relaxed.

Need to know: the economy

The US Federal Reserve is expected to confirm plans this week to raise interest rates for the first time since the onset of the pandemic. According to veteran investor Mohamed El-Erian, it should immediately ditch its asset-purchase programme, guide markets to three or more interest rate rises this year and explain its approach to tackling inflation. Without bold action, its current path risks another, significantly more disruptive policy error later this year, he argues.

Monetary tightening from the likes of the Fed are, however, likely to deepen the gap between “the rich world and those elsewhere”, argues the FT Editorial Board. “Self-interest alone should convince richer countries to act: the consequences of re-emergent poverty, much like viruses, are rarely confined to national borders,” it says.

Latest for the UK and Europe

The World Health Organization's European arm marked the second anniversary of the regional emergence of coronavirus by saying it was hopeful that the “emergency phase” of the pandemic would end this year. The Omicron variant of the virus now accounts for 31.8 per cent of cases across the region, up from 15 per cent in the previous week.

The rise in Omicron infections and continuing restrictions could potentially derail Emmanuel Macron's campaign for a second term as French president, as this article explains.

Global latest

In his Unhedged newsletter, commentator Robert Armstrong warns investors against hitting the panic button after last week's global stock market rout. “Market corrections and shifts in policy regimes are scary. But it does not look like the edge of an abyss, either,” he writes — a view shared by the FT Editorial Board.

New Zealand premier Jacinda Ardern's decision to cancel her wedding highlights the fear in Asia-Pacific countries over the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. China faces a particular challenge with just two weeks to go before the Winter Olympics in Beijing.

Recent major disruptions to supply chains, including the blockage of the Suez Canal and the global semiconductor shortage, led some to predict a boom in technologies such as 3D printing of industrial components, writes Alan Beattie in our Trade Secrets newsletter. Evidence, however, has shown this is likely to remain only a niche activity.

Need to know: business

Airlines said they would be forced to run half-empty, polluting “ghost flights” after the UK announced new rules requiring them to fly more regularly or lose their lucrative airport landing rights. Meanwhile, travel groups are gearing up for a surge in bookings as UK restrictions are eased. The lingering effect of the pandemic on global air travel was illustrated by Cathay Pacific's report this morning of a $783m loss in 2021.

Halliburton, one of the world's top oilfield services companies, followed rivals Schlumberger and Baker Hughes by reporting a surge in profits as the oil industry roars back to life. Net income for the quarter beat estimates to hit $824m, compared with a loss a year earlier. Revenue jumped 32 per cent to hit $4.3bn.

Shares in De La Rue plunged today after the banknote maker warned that pandemic disruption, including a shortage in computer chips, would hit profits.

The World of Work

Executives often wear metaphorical masks when addressing their employees, but how do you assess someone's authenticity when they are wearing a real-life version? Management editor Andrew Hill examines when we should doubt masked leaders and when we should believe them.

“First it was working from home. Now it is the four-day working week that is shaking business life in ways that would have seemed unthinkable before Covid-19,” writes columnist Pilita Clark. The argument for this working style is gaining ground as younger, more open-minded managers take the place of a more conservative old guard, she argues.

Civil servants in England are coming under increasing pressure to return to their offices now that “work from home” coronavirus guidance has been lifted. The issue will be discussed at a Cabinet meeting tomorrow, but the FDA trade union warned against a “reckless, headlong rush” as a member survey showed 90 per cent wanted to continue with hybrid arrangements to maintain a work-life balance.

Qualcomm chief Cristiano Amon tells the FT in our latest How to Lead interview how his company navigated the pandemic surge in demand for computer chips, despite having no control over their production.

And finally...

Spending on virtual or online exercise has rocketed during the pandemic and is expected to grow tenfold from $6bn in 2019 to $60bn by 2027. Read Patrick McGee's essay on the new obsession with connected fitness.
